Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transformational Learning through Undergraduate Research: Comprehensive Support for Faculty, Institutions, State Systems and Consortia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Undergraduate research is a proven form of engaged learning that engenders a transformational experience for undergraduates as a consequence of deep student involvement and frequent student-mentor interactions. The Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) intends to address the critical national need for continued and more comprehensive dissemination of effective practices for initiating and sustaining faculty-student collaborative undergraduate research. This project is a comprehensive expansion of the impact and reach of CUR's Phase 2-supported regional initiative and the organization's national-level "Institutionalizing Undergraduate Research" workshops (held from 1996-2006). The Phase 3 project is providing a series of "Institutionalizing Undergraduate Research" workshops for groups of colleges and universities drawn from state systems, private consortia, and mission-similar institutions (e.g., minority-serving), and employing a structured program of workshop follow-up activities. Training workshops to develop the skills of CUR members to serve as workshop facilitators will enhance the mentoring received by workshop participants, provide avenues for leadership development, and further sustain the initiative with a cadre of trained facilitators throughout the country. More than 150 facilitators and coordinators will be directly involved. The Phase 3 project will be extensively evaluated with the assistance of an independent external evaluator and a distinguished external advisory board.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This five-year project addressed the critical national need for continued and more comprehensive dissemination of effective practices for initiating and sustaining faculty-student collaborative undergraduate research (UGR) as a powerful form of engaged learning and key stratagem to increase STEM student academic and career success. The project was undertaken by the Council on Undergraduate Research (http://www.cur.org).  Five public systems/consortia, including the Council on Public Liberal Arts Colleges (COPLAC), the University of Wisconsin State System (UW), the California State University System (CSU), the City University of New York (CUNY) system, and the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education (PASSHE), and one coalition of private institutions (Great Lakes Colleges Association [GLCA]) participated in the project’s professional development and assessment programs.  A total of 79 higher education institutions participated in a series of professional development events with the goal of helping each system/consortium institutionalize UGR at each of the member campuses and at the system/consortium-level.  The project included a two-workshop sequence hosted by the systems/consortia. The initial workshop series focused on providing specialized curricula uniquely tailored to the specific needs of the system/consortium and addressed such topics as:  faculty hiring, tenure/promotion and workload issues, curriculum case studies, funding, assessment, supporting non-traditional students in UGR, UGR as a high-impact practice, connecting service learning, community-based learning and international education with UGR, establishing ties to research-intensive and doctoral-granting institutions, promoting UGR in all disciplines, and communicating with external constituents.  Individual campus teams left the first workshop with detailed UGR expansion plans linked to system-wide plans. Follow-on workshops for each system/consortium, held approximately one-year later, were held to review progress made on the individual campus and system-wide plans. Formative evaluations conducted by an external evaluator in association with both the first- and second-year workshops demonstrated that systems/consortia were able to achieve growth in building awareness of UGR throughout individual campuses, as well as at the system/consortial office level. In addition the content and delivery of the workshops by Council on Undergraduate Research facilitators was viewed favorably by the workshop participants.

 

By the end of the five-year grant, the six systems and consortia had achieved significant progress in embedding UGR at the institutional level and advancing UGR as a larger collective unit. Evidence for this was provided by a summative evaluation conducted by the external evaluator, and presentations and discussions held at a summit meeting in Washington, D.C. in March of 2014, with representatives from all institutions in the six systems/consortia attending. The summit meeting served to increase inter-system networking, contextualize and validate project findings, and identify future directions of UGR development within systems. A subsequent publication in the Wiley (Jossey-Bass) periodical, New Directions for Higher Education, was published as a special, edited volume in Spring 2015 entitled:  Enhancing and Expanding Undergraduate Research: A Systems Approach. In this publication, each system/coalition’s specific pathway to accomplishing growth in UGR was documented.  http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1119061369.html.
